case_name: Mrs. Kusumben D. Mahadevia v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 507 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 507 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the order and judgment dated September 28, 1955, and February 20, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 28 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated September 28, 1955 and judgment dated February 20, 1956 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 28 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order and judgment dated September 28, 1955, and February 20, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 28 of 1955. J. Kolah and I. N. Shroff, for the appellant.

facts.text: Mrs. Kusumben D. Mahadevia is the assessee and appellant, residing in Bombay at all material times.

anchor.surface_text: Mrs. Kusumben D. Mahadevia  hereinafter referred to as the assessee  who has filed this appeal, was, at all material times, residing in Bombay.

facts.text: Assessee held 760 shares of Mafatlal Gagalbhai Co., Ltd., Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: She was a shareholder, holding 760 shares of Mafatlal Gagalbhai Co., Ltd., Bombay. For the assessment year 1950-51  the previous year being the calendar year 1949 ,

facts.text: For assessment year 1950-51 (previous year calendar year 1949), assessee assessed to income-tax on total income of Rs. 1,50,765 including grossed-up dividend income of Rs. 1,47,026.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1950-51  the previous year being the calendar year 1949 , she was assessed to income-tax on a total income of Rs. 1,50,765 which included a grossed-up dividend income of Rs. 1,47,026.

facts.text: Grossed-up dividend income included Rs. 47,120 being dividends declared by Mafatlal Gagalbhai Co., Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: In the latter income was included a sum of Rs. 47,120 being the dividends declared by Mafatlal Gagalbhai Co., Ltd., Bombay.

facts.text: Mafatlal Gagalbhai Co., Ltd. is a private limited company with registered office at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Mafatlal Gagalbhai Co., Ltd., is a private limited Company with its registered office at Bombay. It was, at all material times, resident and ordinarily resident in British India.

facts.text: Company was resident and ordinarily resident in British India at all material times.

anchor.surface_text: It was, at all material times, resident and ordinarily resident in British India. It was also doing business in the former Baroda State,

facts.text: Company doing business in former Baroda State and kept profits derived there with Mafatlal Gagalbhai Investment Corporation, Navsari.

anchor.surface_text: It was also doing business in the former Baroda State, and used to keep its profits derived in that State with Mafatlal Gagalbhai Investment Corporation, Navsari.

facts.text: In the year 1949, company declared dividends out of accumulated profits by three resolutions.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1949 Mafatlal Gagalbhai Co., Ltd., declared dividends out of these accumulated profits by three resolutions, which are reproduced 25-3-1949.

facts.text: Resolution dated 25-3-1949: further dividend of Rs. 17 per ordinary share free of income-tax for year 1947 absorbing Rs. 4,29,250 payable in Navsari out of profits of 1947 lying at Navsari.

anchor.surface_text: 25-3-1949. That a further dividend of Rs. 17 per ordinary share free of income-tax for the year 1947 be and is hereby declared absorbing Rs. 4,29,250 and the same be payable in Navsari out of the profits of the year 1947 lying at Navsari.

facts.text: Resolution dated 24-9-1949: further dividend Rs. 24 per ordinary share free of income-tax for 1948 absorbing Rs. 6,06,000 payable in Navsari on or after 30th April 1949.

anchor.surface_text: 24-9-1949. That a further dividend of Rs. 24 per ordinary share free of income-tax for the year 1948 be and is hereby declared absorbing Rs. 6,06,000 and the same be payable in Navsari out of the profits of the year 1948 lying at Navsari with Messrs. M.G. Investment Corporation Ltd. on -or after 30th April, 1949.

facts.text: Resolution dated 24-9-1949: Ad-interim dividend Rs. 21 per ordinary share free of income-tax for 1949 absorbing Rs. 5,30,250 payable in Navsari on or after 30th April 1949.

anchor.surface_text: 24-9-1949. Resolved that an Ad-interim dividend of Rs. 21 per ordinary share free of income-tax absorbing Rs. 5,30,250 be and is hereby declared for the year 1949 out of the income of the Company for the year 1949 remaining unbrought with Messrs. M. G. Investment Corporation Ltd., Navsari, and that the same be payable in Navsari on or after 30th April, 1949.

facts.text: Assessee did not bring these dividends into British India.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee did number bring these dividends into British India.

facts.text: Assessee claimed benefit of para. 4 of the Merged States Taxation Concessions Order, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: She claimed the benefit of para. 4 of the Merged States  Taxation Concessions  Order, 1949  hereinafter referred to briefly as the Concessions Order  but the Tribunal held

facts.text: Tribunal held that the income did not accrue to assessee in the Baroda State.

anchor.surface_text: but the Tribunal held that the income did number accrue to her in the Baroda State. The Tribunal pointed out that the dividends were declared by Mafatlal Gagalbhai Co., Ltd.,

facts.text: Tribunal stated dividends declared out of composite profits accrued partly in British India and partly in Indian State.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal pointed out that the dividends were declared by Mafatlal Gagalbhai Co., Ltd., out of its profits which had accrued partly in, what was then called, British India and partly in the Indian State.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court: Whether the net dividend income of Rs. 47,120 accrued to the assessee in the former Baroda State, or whether it is income accrued or deemed to have accrued to the assessee in British India?

anchor.surface_text: the assessee drew up a statement of the case under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, and referred the following question to the High Court Whether the net dividend income of Rs. 47,120 accrued to the assessee in the former Baroda State, or whether it is income accrued or deemed to have accrued to the assessee in British India ?

facts.text: High Court by order dated September 28, 1955 reframed the question.

anchor.surface_text: When the reference was heard, the High Court was of the opinion that the Tribunal ought to have decided and referred also the question whether the Concessions Order applied to the assessee.

facts.text: High Court reframed question to: Whether the assessee is entitled to any concession under the Merged States Taxation Concessions Order, 1949, with regard to the net dividend income of Rs. 47,120?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court then reframed the question, as it said, to companyprehend the two points of law in the following words Whether the assessee is entitled to any companycession under the Merged States  Taxation Concessions  Order, 1949, with regard to the net dividend income of Rs. 47,120?

facts.text: High Court on February 20, 1956 answered the reframed question in the negative, holding para 4 of Concessions Order did not apply.

anchor.surface_text: The reference then came up for final disposal on February 20, 1956, and the High Court answered the question in the negative, holding that para. 4 of the Concessions Order did number apply to the assessee.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal against both the order and judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Leave to appeal to this Court was refused by the High Court, but the assessee applied to this Court for special leave against both the order and the judgment and obtained it, and the present appeal has been filed.

facts.text: Tribunal did not address applicability of Concessions Order to assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal did number address itself to the question whether the Concessions Order applied to the assessee. It decided the question of assessability on the short ground

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court exceeded jurisdiction by deciding question not arising from Tribunal's order.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we are of opinion that the High Court exceeded its jurisdiction in going outside the point of law decided by the Tribunal and deciding a different point of law.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court order and remits case to High Court to decide question framed by Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the High Court will, therefore, be set aside, and the case will be remitted to the High Court to decide the question framed by the Tribunal.
Appeal No. 507 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the order and judgment dated September 28, 1955, and February 20, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 28 of 1955.
The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is an appeal with the special leave of this Court, and is directed against an order dated September 28, 1955,
Leave to appeal to this Court was refused by the High Court, but the assessee applied to this Court for special leave against both the order and the judgment and obtained it,
under s. 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, and referred the following question to the High Court Whether the net dividend income of Rs. 47,120 accrued to the assessee

concepts.unlisted_description: Governs reference of questions of law by Tribunal to High Court

anchor.surface_text: Section 66 of the Income-tax Act which confers jurisdiction upon the High Court only permits a reference of a question of law arising out of the order of the Tribunal. It does not confer jurisdiction on the High Court to decide a different question of law not arising out of such order.

concepts.interpretation: Confers jurisdiction on High Court only to decide questions of law arising out of Tribunal's order; does not permit deciding entirely different questions not considered by Tribunal even if leading to same result

issues.text: Whether the net dividend income of Rs. 47,120 accrued to the assessee in the former Baroda State, or whether it is income accrued or deemed to have accrued to the assessee in British India ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the net dividend income of Rs. 47,120 accrued to the assessee in the former Baroda State, or whether it is income accrued or deemed to have accrued to the assessee in British India ?

issues.text: Whether the assessee is entitled to any concession under the Merged States Taxation Concessions Order, 1949, with regard to the net dividend income of Rs. 47,120?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the assessee is entitled to any concession under the Merged States Taxation Concessions Order, 1949, with regard to the net dividend income of Rs. 47,120?

issues.text: Whether the High Court had jurisdiction to frame and deal with a question of law not arising out of the order of the Tribunal under Section 66 of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: At the very outset, the assessee has questioned the jurisdiction of the High Court to frame and deal with a question of law not arising out of the order of the Tribunal.

arguments.claim: The dividend income did not accrue to the assessee in the Baroda State because the dividends were declared out of composite profits partly from British India and the shares were an asset situated in British India

anchor.surface_text: but the Tribunal held that the income did number accrue to her in the Baroda State. The Tribunal pointed out that the dividends were declared by Mafatlal Gagalbhai Co., Ltd., out of its profits which had accrued partly in, what was then called, British India and partly in the Indian State. The dividend was thus declared out of companyposite profits. It further pointed out that the assessee had paid for and acquired the shares of a Company in British India and was thus holding an asset in British India, and that the income was from that asset.

arguments.claim: Assessee is entitled to the benefit of para 4 of the Merged States Taxation Concessions Order 1949 in respect of the dividend income

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court lacked jurisdiction to decide this question as it did not arise from Tribunal order; order set aside and remitted

arguments.claim: High Court lacked jurisdiction under s66 to frame and decide a question of law not arising out of the Tribunal's order, namely applicability of Concessions Order

anchor.surface_text: At the very outset, the assessee has questioned the jurisdiction of the High Court to frame and deal with a question of law number arising out of the order of the Tribunal. The assessee points out that the Tribunal had decided that the income had accrued in British India.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hether the Concessions Order applied to the assessee. It decided the question of assessability on the short ground that the income had number arisen i

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal decided accrual point without addressing Concessions Order; points not co-extensive or included in each other; s66 does not permit deciding different question

arguments.claim: High Court had jurisdiction to reframe comprehensive question on entitlement to concession as accrual question was ancillary and included in assessability under Concessions Order

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel for the Commissioner, on the other hand, companytends that the question was the assessability of the assessee, who claimed the benefit of the Concessions Order. The main question was thus the applicability of the Concessions Order, and the question of the accrual of the income, whether in British India or in Baroda, was merely ancillary.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hether the Concessions Order applied to the assessee. It decided the question of assessability on the short ground that the income had number arisen i

arguments.court_reasoning: Questions neither co-extensive nor one included in the other; accrual decided under Income-tax Act independent of Concessions Order

arguments.claim: Section 66 of Income-tax Act confers jurisdiction on High Court only for questions of law arising out of Tribunal order and does not permit deciding a different question of law

anchor.surface_text: Section 66 of the Income-tax Act which companyfers jurisdiction upon the High Court only permits a reference of a question of law arising out of the order of the Tribunal. It does number companyfer jurisdiction on the High Court to decide a different question of law not arising out of such order.

arguments.claim: Cases cited by respondent (Scindia Steam, Breach Candy, Ismailia Grain) are distinguishable as they involved widening existing questions, not entirely different issues

anchor.surface_text: The respondent referred to Scindia Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income- tax 1 , Commissioner of Income-tax v. Breach Candy Swimming Bath Trust 2 and Ismailia Grain Merchants Association v. Commissioner of Income-tax 3 . They were all decisions of the same Court, and arose in different circumstances.

holdings.text: The High Court exceeded its jurisdiction in going outside the point of law decided by the Tribunal and deciding a different point of law.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we are of opinion that the High Court exceeded its jurisdiction in going outside the point of law decided by the Tribunal and deciding a different point of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal decided only accrual of income in British India without addressing Concessions Order applicability; High Court decided Concessions Order instead; two points distinct, neither co-extensive nor included; s.66 limits jurisdiction to questions arising from Tribunal order.

holdings.text: Section 66 of the Income-tax Act confers jurisdiction upon the High Court only to permit a reference of a question of law arising out of the order of the Tribunal and does not confer jurisdiction to decide a different question of law not arising out of such order.

anchor.surface_text: Section 66 of the Income-tax Act which confers jurisdiction upon the High Court only permits a reference of a question of law arising out of the order of the Tribunal. It does not confer jurisdiction on the High Court to decide a different question of law not arising out of such order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court may amplify question for different approaches to same question decided by Tribunal but cannot decide entirely different question never considered by Tribunal.

holdings.text: The question of accrual of income under the Income-tax Act and applicability of the Concessions Order are neither co-extensive nor one included in the other.

anchor.surface_text: But the two matters were neither coextensive, nor was the one included in the other. The question of accrual of income has to be decided under the Income-tax Act, and has but little to do with the Concessions Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accrual decided independently under Income-tax Act without need for Concessions Order; Tribunal decided accrual, High Court decided Concessions Order applicability.

holdings.text: The cases cited by the respondent (Scindia Steam, Breach Candy, Ismailia Grain) are distinguishable as they involved widening existing questions, not deciding entirely different issues.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent referred to Scindia Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income- tax 1 , Commissioner of Income-tax v. Breach Candy Swimming Bath Trust 2 and Ismailia Grain Merchants Association v. Commissioner of Income-tax 3 . They were all decisions of the same Court, and arose in different circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: In cited cases, questions widened existing Tribunal issues or deleted section references; here, Tribunal and High Court decided entirely different legal issues.

holdings.text: The order of the High Court will be set aside, and the case remitted to the High Court to decide the question framed by the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the High Court will, therefore, be set aside, and the case will be remitted to the High Court to decide the question framed by the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequent to finding of excess jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we are of opinion that the High Court exceeded its jurisdiction in going outside the point of law decided by the Tribunal and deciding a different point of law.
The order of the High Court will, therefore, be set aside, and the case will be remitted to the High Court to decide the question framed by the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Section 66 of the Income-tax Act which confers jurisdiction upon the High Court only permits a reference of a question of law arising out of the order of the Tribunal. It does not confer jurisdiction on the High Court to decide a different question of law not arising out of such order.
The order of the High Court will, therefore, be set aside, and the case will be remitted to the High Court to decide the question framed by the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: But the two matters were neither coextensive, nor was the one included in the other. The question of accrual of income has to be decided under the Income-tax Act, and has but little to do with the Concessions Order.
The order of the High Court will, therefore, be set aside, and the case will be remitted to the High Court to decide the question framed by the Tribunal.
Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income- tax  1 , Commissioner of Income-tax v. Breach Candy Swimming Bath Trust  2   and Ismailia Grain Merchants Associa

anchor.surface_text: The respondent referred to Scindia Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income- tax 1 , Commissioner of Income-tax v. Breach Candy Swimming Bath Trust 2 and Ismailia Grain Merchants Association v. Commissioner of Income-tax 3 . They were all decisions of the same Court, and arose in different circumstances.
The order of the High Court will, therefore, be set aside, and the case will be remitted to the High Court to decide the question framed by the Tribunal.
